title: State Agrees To Pay 1 3m For Never Built Migrant Tent Encampment Despite Gov Jb Pritzkers Assurances

Antonio Perez/Chicago TribuneA worker sprays water on a sidewalk outside a fenced former parking lot along 38th Street, the site of the possible migrant tent city. John J. Kim/Chicago TribuneSofia Salinas walks along the fenced-in area that was to become a migrant tent encampment near her home in the Brighton Park neighborhood, Dec. 14, 2023, in Chicago. Salinas and her neighbors are concerned about the presence of ground chemicals on the site that prevented the encampment from opening. She said all of the construction that had been completed was taken down fully by the previous night. Despite assurances from Gov. JB Pritzker that state taxpayers would not end up footing the bill for a migrant tent encampment in Chicago that was never built, the state recently agreed to pay $1.3 million to the project’s contractor. Pritzker made thehighly publicized decisionto halt construction of the shelter encampment in Chicago’s Brighton Park neighborhood in December 2023, saying “serious environmental concerns” were still present at the city-selected site. The governor’s decision caused theBrighton Park projectto be scrapped, and it signaled an early political rift between the governor and Mayor Brandon Johnson, who was pushing for the shelter to be built as winter arrived and the migrant crisis in the city continued. Pritzker that month also made public assurances that the project’s state contractor, GardaWorld Federal Services, would absorb the costs of the work that it had already put into constructing the camp. “The understanding with GardaWorld is that they will do other work with us,” Pritzkertold reportersat an unrelated event in December 2023. “And they knew, as they were building this shelter, before the environmental report came in, that it was possible that the environmental report wouldn’t allow the building — the completion, rather — of the shelter. And so they understood that, and they were willing to take that liability on through the state’s contract.” Officials with Pritzker’s office also said the company had agreed not to charge the state if the land was deemed unsafe. But a $1.3 million payment to GardaWorld was tucked into the recently approved $55 billion state spending plan being sent to Pritzker’s desk. And Pritzker’s Illinois Department of Human Services, which spearheaded the state’s portion of the migrant response, agreed this April to settle a dispute with GardaWorld over payment for its work at the site, other state records show. In response to questions about the apparent contradiction, a Pritzker spokesman maintained that “GardaWorld had no contractual right to payment.” Nevertheless, the state agreed to pay the company because “the situation evolved,” Pritzker spokesman Alex Gough said. Neither Pritzker’s office nor officials with the state Human Services Department would explain why the state agreed to pay if it was under no legal obligation to do so. GardaWorld did not respond to requests for comment. The so-calledbase camp at the former industrial siteat 38th Street and California Avenue was initially pitched in the fall of 2023 as a way to safely house migrants who arrived from the southern border in such large numbers that the city’s shelter system was overwhelmed. At the time, more than 24,000 migrants had come to Chicago, mostly hailing from Central and South America, with the influx being so great during fall 2023 that a peak of about 3,800 arrivals were camped at police stations and O’Hare International Airport. Johnson initially unveiled the general tent camp idea in September 2023. While Pritzker publicly said at the time he preferred to use existing buildings if possible,the Tribune later revealedPritzker’s administration had first pitched the idea of “outdoor (soft sided)” lodging options even before Johnson took office. Once Johnson did formally present the idea, he suggested the city could place asylum-seekers in heated winter tents, and theBrighton Park base campcould house approximately 2,000 migrants at a time as they waited for brick-and-mortar shelters to become available. While Pritzker pledged $65 million in state funding for tent encampment work, the Brighton Park site could not be opened until it cleared an environmental study. Despite that, just after Thanksgiving of 2023 and before the environmental report was concluded, GardaWorld began construction on the site, with the governor later saying the company had agreed not to charge the state if the land was deemed unsafe. That happened weeks later with the release of the city’s environmental review late on a Friday evening. Pritzker’s staff saw its contents at roughly the same time as those who’d filed open records requests for the nearly 800-page document and the governor’s office said the site was not safe to house people. The incident set off days of finger-pointing between the governor’s office and City Hall and stirred controversy and inflamed tensions between Pritzker and Johnson early in the new mayor’s tenure. Now, according to records from the Illinois Court of Claims, which handles monetary claims against the state, the Human Services Department and the contractor were “in agreement” that GardaWorld was owed $1.3 million “for services rendered at the 38th and California site” during the state budget year that ended June 30, 2024. They also agreed that the money would be “considered full payment and satisfaction of all claims by GardaWorld against the Illinois Department of Human Services” for the site work. The state payment, to be made in the state budget year that begins July 1 if Pritzker signs the spending plan as expected, would essentially close the books on the unrealized migrant tent encampment plan. But it isn’t the only cost borne by taxpayers for the unused site. Aside from the money the state is set to pay out, the city spent about $1.7 million on environmental remediation and a settlement with the property’s owner. The mayor’s office has said the remediation will provide “a lasting community benefit.” Republicans nationally have long blamed the migrant crisis on what they characterized as former President Joe Biden’s failure to enforce immigration laws. The Illinois GOP also blamed Pritzker and other Democrats in Springfield for enacting policies that welcome immigrants and provide government services regardless of legal status. The Democrats in Washington, D.C., Springfield and elsewhere, meanwhile, faulted congressional Republicans for blocking comprehensive efforts to overhaul the immigration system and GOP governors for sending migrants to other states with little care for what would happen to them after they arrived at more northern locales. “It’s clear taxpayers are still on the hook for the migrant crisis of the Democrat majority’s making,” Illinois House Republican Leader Tony McCombie of Savanna said in a recent statement. “This is just one of the many repercussions taxpayers will face for continued agency mismanagement under the Pritzker administration.” About a month after the brouhaha between Pritzker and Johnson over the Brighton Park site, the state opened a long-discussed but much smaller shelter in a former CVS store in the Little Village neighborhood. The shelter, large enough to accommodate about 300 migrants, was operated by GardaWorld and nonprofit New Life Centers and closed after about 10 months in late October 2024. GardaWorld also worked with the state to open two other shelters last summer: One in a recently renovated Holiday Inn in the West Lawn neighborhood that could house up to 1,700 people and another 750-bed facility for families in a former Hyde Park hotel. Migrant and homeless shelters have since been merged through the “One System Initiative.” GardaWorld completed its work with the state Human Services Department in January, an agency spokeswoman said. Over the past two years, the state has paid the Virginia-based company nearly $46.7 million, according to the state comptroller’s office. Chicago Tribune’s Jeremy Gorner contributed. **Share this:** Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Facebook Click to share on Bluesky (Opens in new window)Bluesky Click to share on X (Opens in new window)X Click to print (Opens in new window)Print Click to email a link to a friend (Opens in new window)Email **RevContent Feed** **Most Popular** 17 arrested as Chicago protesters march against Donald Trump’s immigration crackdown17 arrested as Chicago protesters march against Donald Trump's immigration crackdown **17 arrested as Chicago protesters march against Donald Trump’s immigration crackdown** **17 arrested as Chicago protesters march against Donald Trump’s immigration crackdown** Daily Horoscope for June 11, 2025Daily Horoscope for June 11, 2025 **Daily Horoscope for June 11, 2025** **Daily Horoscope for June 11, 2025** Daily Horoscope for June 10, 2025Daily Horoscope for June 10, 2025 **Daily Horoscope for June 10, 2025** **Daily Horoscope for June 10, 2025** Loss of over-the-air TV leaves some Chicago sports fans frustrated with new CHSN-Comcast dealLoss of over-the-air TV leaves some Chicago sports fans frustrated with new CHSN-Comcast deal **Loss of over-the-air TV leaves some Chicago sports fans frustrated with new CHSN-Comcast deal** **Loss of over-the-air TV leaves some Chicago sports fans frustrated with new CHSN-Comcast deal** State agrees to pay $1.3M for never-built migrant tent encampment despite Gov.
